item.title: James Haeck Hired By Wizards of the Coast as Senior Designer for Dungeons & Dragons
item.content:encoded:
Wizards of the Coast has hired a new Senior Designer for Dungeons & Dragons. James Haeck, whose body of work includes many acclaimed supplements and modules for the world's most popular fantasy TTRPG, will now help shape that game for the future.

In a report from EN World, James Haeck announced on Ghostfire Games' Eldritch Lorecast podcast that he would be joining Wizards of the Coast's as a senior Dungeons & Dragons designer. Haeck will join other writers who have been similarly promoted, including Game Design Director Justice Ramin Arman (Journeys Through the Radiant Citadel), Makenzie de Armas (Vecna: Eve of Ruin), and James Wyatt (Van Richten's Guide to Ravenloft).

Like his peers, James Haeck has had a prolific career within the TTRPG space. He has written official Dungeons & Dragons material for several years as a freelancer and is an Ennie Award-winning game designer. This work includes acclaimed modules like Waterdeep: Dragon Heist and Baldur's Gate: Descent into Avernus.

In addition, Haeck has contributed to other publications. These include Draw Steel developer MCDM and Ghostfire Games. His biggest contribution was to Darrington Press' Critical Role. He has written for Explorer's Guide to Wildemount, Tal'Dorei Reborn, and was a co-writer on the Call of the Netherdeep module.

The hiring of James Haeck by Wizards of the Coast appears to be an attempt to retain developer talent after the departure of creative leads Jeremy Crawford and Chris Perkins. 

It can also be speculated that this new creative team may be working on a new wave of Dungeons & Dragons supplements in the style of the recent Forgotten Realms books and Eberron: Forge of the Artificer. While Wizards of the Coast has been quiet, rumor has it that future books may include the debut of a new core class, the Psion, and potentially a return to the controversial post-apocalyptic Dark Sun setting.

Ever since he was small, Tyler Chancey has had a deep, abiding love for video games and a tendency to think and overanalyze everything he enjoyed. Thisâ€¦ More about Tyler
